reps.thinking: The notebook provides a detailed description including the Dandiset title, ID, purpose, data contents, and the organization, and relevant aspects of the key metadata.

The notebook provides a clear and comprehensive description of the Dandiset. It includes the title, ID, purpose, content (neuronal responses during tFUS), and some key metadata fields like subject ID, species, sex, age, and a description of the experimental setup. The notebook also lists the number of assets and the size of the files. The data organization is implicit in the overview of the NWB file contents. Thus, the notebook provides a comprehensive description of the Dandiset contents and structure. The autogenerated disclaimer is noted.

This notebook provides a clear and comprehensive description of the Dandiset. It includes the title, ID, purpose, content, and basic metadata. Additionally, it provides information on data organization within the NWB file. Therefore, level 10 is suitable.

The notebook loads the Dandiset ID and lists the files. It then loads substantial metadata such as session description, subject ID, species, sex, age etc. It also lists acquisition keys/intervals keys, ElectricalSeries shape and number of trials. It displays basic metadata fields and explores multiple metadata fields. Electrode metadata is also explored. I'm giving this a 7 because it explores a good range of metadata available in the Dandiset.

The notebook effectively loads and displays Dandiset metadata. It starts by using the DANDI API to list the assets and then loads an NWB file using a URL. Basic metadata fields such as session description, identifier, and start time are printed. Further, subject metadata including ID, species, sex, age, and description are also extracted and displayed. Thus, the notebook demonstrates the loading and exploration of multiple metadata fields, placing it in category 7.

The notebook lists dandiset assets from the DANDI API and extracts relevant information about the subject from the file. This includes loading the dandiset id. The notebook also presents descriptions of the file and dataset in markdown cells, and lists the session start time. The notebook also prints the number of assets in the dandiset, lists subject metadata (ID, species, sex, age, description), and it lists acquisition and intervals keys, amongst other basic metadata. Therefore, I believe this should be closer to a 7.

The notebook initially lists the dandiset assets and sizes, which is useful for selection and understanding data scale. It then successfully loads an NWB file using lindi and pynwb, and prints session description, identifier, and start time. Furthermore, it extracts and prints subject metadata (ID, species, sex, age, description). The notebook shows how to get keys from acquisitions and intervals, so I believe a score of 7 is appropriate.

The notebook successfully lists the available assets in the Dandiset using the DANDI API. It then proceeds to load a specific NWB file from the Dandiset using its URL, demonstrating how to load specific assets. The notebook accesses asset metadata by printing session descriptions, identifier, and start time. It further accesses subject metadata and shows how to extract trials information and electrode metadata. Therefore, it goes beyond simply listing assets and loads and explores a specific one.

The notebook demonstrates loading specific assets using the DANDI API, specifically, it loads information from an NWB file. It also lists available assets. It shows how to access and print this asset metadata, along with subject metadata.

The notebook lists and loads asset information i.e. shows how to list the assets in the Dandiset, then loads a specific asset using pynwb and lindi. After this, it extracts basic info from the loaded NWB file, such as the session description, subject metadata, and electrode metadata. The notebook demonstrates a good grasp of loading and accessing asset information, meriting a score of 6. It loads specific assets, but does not comprehensively go into metadata exploration, or demonstrate usage examples thoroughly although it does plot some data from the open file.

The notebook successfully opens an NWB file, accesses basic components such as session description, subject ID, acquisition data, intervals (trials), and electrode metadata. It also visualizes a snippet of the data. Therefore, the notebook demonstrates accessing basic NWB components and exploring multiple NWB data structures.

The notebook successfully loads an NWB file, prints basic info such as session description, identifier, and start time (score 4). It also explores subject metadata (score 5). Furthermore, it obtains the keys for acquisitions and intervals, prints the shape and sampling rate of the ElectricalSeries, and the number of trials (score 6). It lists electrode metadata column names and their values (score 7).

The notebook shows how to load an NWB file from the DANDI archive. It loads basic information like session description, subject ID, species, sex, age, acquisition keys, intervals keys, electrical series shape, sampling rate, the number of trials, explore electrode metadata and visualizes snippet of data around a trial onset ,which demonstrates accessing, displaying the basic NWB components and structure. The notebook therefore does a reasonably good job demonstrating access to the basic NWB file contents and structure.

The notebook successfully loads an NWB file from the DANDI archive using lindi and pynwb. It then proceeds to access and print various metadata elements like session description, identifier, session start time, subject metadata, acquisition keys, intervals keys, electrical series shape, sampling rate, and number of trials. Furthermore, it accesses and prints electrode metadata, including column names and values for each column. Finally, it visualizes a snippet of the electrical series data. Thus, the notebook loads the data and demonstrate loading various different data types appropriately..

The notebook successfully loads an NWB file from a DANDI archive using lindi and pynwb, then proceeds to access and print information about the session, subject, acquisitions, intervals, and electrodes. In a subsequent cell, it loads and visualizes a signal snippet, which demonstrates loading data arrays from the NWB file. Therefore, it demonstrates loading specific data types and accessing multiple data elements. The notebook does not demonstrate many advanced techniques, however.

The notebook successfully loads an NWB file from the DANDI archive using pynwb and lindi. It then proceeds to extract and print basic metadata such as session description, subject information, acquisition data (ElectricalSeries shape and sampling rate), and trial information. The notebook also explores electrode metadata. Therefore the notebook shows how to load data from an NWB file in the Dandiset, and the information loaded is more than just data arrays, but also metadata. The data handled includes numerical data (electrode positions, electrical series), strings (session descriptions), and tables (trials).

The notebook displays how to load an NWB file and then visualizes a small snippet of the electrophysiology data.  The axes are labeled but it only shows one basic visualization type, and one specific example. Some processing (scaling, offset) is included. Overall it's a reasonable basic viz but not advanced or even comprehensive.

The notebook presents a basic visualization of ecephys data, specifically a snippet of continuous raw signals around a randomly selected trial onset. The plot is labeled, and the code is functional, though it only demonstrates one type of visualization. Also, there is no interactive element in the plots.

The notebook includes code to load NWB files and plot a snippet of electrophysiological data around a random trial onset. The plot has axis labels and a title. The code executes without errors. Therefore, the notebook creates simple visualizations of one data type(electrophysiological data).

The notebook contains one plot. The plot is readable, has labels, and is properly formatted with a descriptive title. There are some overlap in the labels of the y axis, which somewhat affects readability.
The notebook contains a readable plot with basic labels (x and y axes are labeled), a title, and a legend. The formatting is acceptable.

The notebook contains one plot that is properly labeled and formatted. The plot contains several voltage traces offset for readability. The axes are labeled, and the title is descriptive. While the plot is not exceptionally detailed, it is more than sufficient for exploratory data analysis.

The notebook contains a single plot that displays a snippet of the neural data around a trial onset. While the plot is informative, it is a single basic plot. Therefore, it merits a score of 2 based on the rubric.
The notebook contains only one plot that shows raw signals around a trial onset. Therefore, the notebook only contains a single basic plot.

The notebook showcases one plot, which displays a snippet of data around a trial onset. While a basic plot, it is effectively employed to visualize the neural signals across channels. Thus, I will give a score of 2.
